ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Critical perspectives of literature, writing papers from a critical perspective and engaging in diverse literature.

Throughout the course I grew much more confident analyzing literature, both in my papers and in class discussions. I also learned a lot about important American writers, and I feel I got a good introduction to the general arc/development of American literature.
I learned to do close readings, read texts in the context of their historical period, and apply literary criticism to my analyses.

How to write an essay about close reading, broke a bunch of bad habits that they teach you in high school but aren't necessarily the best for real college writing, placing books into their historical contexts and seeing how that changes your understanding of the work. It's a really solid foundational course in literature
I learned how to write a close-reading essay. I also learned about the history of the United States from diverse perspectives.

Developed strong reading and writing skillsespecially learning to write in a way that prioritizes clarity. Introduced me to authors I hadn't known and showed their impact, while also giving new meaning to incredibly famous American works
My writing improved significantly! After every essay, Warner sat down with me and went through line by line.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Thoughtful reading selections, clear and organized syllabus, supportive and passionate staff

Weaknesses: Some assumed knowledge. Assignments were sometimes not explained thoroughly to someone without a strong literary background.

Professor Warner was great; his insights in class were always interesting and illuminating, and I found his feedback on my writing very helpful. The readings can be a lot, but they are well-spaced throughout the semester.
maybe move through books a little more slowly, i found we were rushing through content rather than really engaging with it

The strength of this class was the in-depth knowledge and high engagement from Professor Warner, who truly made this class interesting for me. Its weakness was reading difficult and dense texts at a very fast pace.

STRENGTHS: good mix of books in the curriculum, liked the discussions in class, workload is reasonable. WEAKNESSES: none. I do wish that there was a way for introverts to actively participate more in the class discussions, but the professor does have a weekly reading response in place and he encourages everyone to talk, so there isn't really a weakness.
I think the books selected for this course are absolutely phenomenal; however, a novel from the perspective of an Asian-American or Latinx person would be great!

Strengths: consistent work and expectations; clear directions/instructions; freedom in terms of what to write about; open and illuminating discussion
Weaknesses: hard time thinking of any. Don't get to spend much time on any one work but that's a fault of it being a survey course rather than the teaching of the course or anything like that
The discussion was the only weak point.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. An amazing foundational course with overlaps in history, philosophy, politics, and social issues. Exciting and engaging readings and very beneficial to build a solid foundation of effective writing.

Yes! Professor Warner was amazing -- I really looked forward to class discussions, and I felt I learned a lot about important American writers and improved my writing and literary analysis skills. I really enjoyed the reading selection, and I thought Professor Warner did a great job leading discussions and providing context for the books we read.
Yes.
I'm only taking ENGL 127 because it's an English major requirement. If you're going to take it, take it with Professor Warner.
Yes, if you are an English, Literature, or Humanities major I would highly recommend this course. It is an important literary foundation.

Yes, both for students who are only doing it for a writing credit and for experienced students who want to become English majors. There was a good mix when I took it, and I learned a lot from the seminar-style discussions. Professor Warner is also very compassionate and helpful

Yes, I would 100% recommend this course to another student. The literature is rich and diverse. The discussions will open your mind to new perspectives. Most importantly, Professor Warner is absolutely amazing and, in my opinion, a must have professor at Yale!

Yes, would highly recommend, even if you aren't an English major. Loved the readings and made me a much better writer. Also if you get the chance, take it with Michael Warner. So intelligent and offers really personalized and helpful feedback.
Yes, just have some prior experience with Yale English classes.
